slides.title: Introduction
slides.content:
Welcome, Explorers, to a new Community Lesson!

In web3, everything starts with community. Thanks to blockchain technology and Ethereum, communities can now do more than just coordinate! They can take action, govern shared resources, fund aligned projects, and support the future they want to see üå±

In this lesson, you‚Äôll explore how public goods, DAOs, NFTs, and onchain governance come together in a bold experiment called Public Nouns. Think of open-source tools, Ethereum infrastructure, or free educational platforms like Bankless Academy. These are digital public goods. They can benefit everyone, but since they are not profit-driven, they‚Äôre generally hard to fund.

To tackle the challenge, Public Nouns raised a question: What if a decentralized community could fund these goods directly using art, culture, and code? üë®üèª‚Äçüíª

Let‚Äôs find out what happens when people care enough to build! ‚öíÔ∏è

slides.title: Public goods are good
slides.content:
To start, let‚Äôs learn what public goods are üí°

Public goods are resources that everyone can access, and one person‚Äôs use doesn‚Äôt reduce its availability to others.

In more economic terms, they are non-excludable and non-rivalrous.

It might be a difficult concept to grasp at first, but think of clean air, streetlights, and public spaces like libraries and parks üå≥

In web3, public goods include things like open-source code (such as Ethereum clients), shared infrastructure, and free educational resources like tutorials and documentation. These are the digital commons that can be used by everyone, and their availability isn‚Äôt reduced if used üåê

Public Nouns is a web3-native attempt to support these goods without middlemen, using art, community and culture üé®

quiz.question: What‚Äôs true about public goods?

slides.title: Using web3 to fund public goods
slides.content:
To understand how web3 enables funding for public goods, we need to define its core building blocks üß±

If you‚Äôre already familiar with them, you‚Äôll be able to engage with the next slides more confidently. If not, do not worry, we encourage you to read carefully, as these are foundational ideas that will help everything else make sense.

We‚Äôll cover:

  • NFTs: non-fungible tokens used for identity and coordination üñºÔ∏è
  • DAOs: decentralized autonomous organizations with shared treasuries üåê
  • Onchain governance: transparent, code-based systems for collective decisions üó≥Ô∏è

These elements come together in a unique case study: Public Nouns, a community experiment for public goods funding.

slides.title: What is an NFT? The role of meme culture
slides.content:
NFT stands for non-fungible token, a unique digital item that lives on a blockchain. Unlike tokens that are interchangeable (like ETH or USDC), each NFT is distinct üò≤

NFTs can represent many things: art, music, identity, status, or access. But in the case of Public Nouns, they‚Äôre symbols of shared values.

Each Public Noun features distinctive artwork that represents a public goods project. These visuals act as shared symbols within each community and the Ethereum ecosystem as a whole.

Examples of featured projects include MolochDAO, Gitcoin, Treegens, and more. As communities emerge and others wind down, Public Nouners can also propose new art/communities to be included üó≥Ô∏è

The art draws from meme culture, but here, memes do more than make us smile. They define cultural identity and help people coordinate around a shared mission üéØ

quiz.question: What does a Public Nouns NFT represent?
answers: Speculative art with no intrinsic value

slides.title: What is a DAO?
slides.content:
A DAO, or Decentralized Autonomous Organization, is a web3-native structure for making collective decisions. It manages a shared treasury and its community members vote on new initiatives and how to fund them, openly and without middlemen ‚õìÔ∏è

DAOs were born on Ethereum. Smart contracts, self-executing programs deployed on the blockchain, have made it possible to automate coordination through code. These programs define the rules: who can propose a project, how votes are counted, and when funds are released üîì

Public Nouns is a DAO. If you hold in your Ethereum wallet a Public Noun NFT, you‚Äôre part of the DAO. You can propose new projects, vote on proposals, and help decide which public goods get supported üó≥Ô∏è

There are many kinds of DAOs. Some manage protocols, others invest capital, and some, like Public Nouns, exist to support public goods. Its mission is to create impact, not profit.

slides.title: Forking & Governance Contracts
slides.content:
Public Nouns is a fork of Nouns. In web3, forking means copying open-source code and adapting it for a new mission. Public Nouns kept the daily auction model, but instead of having random characters with different traits, each NFT features symbolic artwork tied to a public good.

The system relies on three core contracts, each with a specific role:

  • Auction: handles timing and sales of NFTs üñºÔ∏è
  • Treasury: holds the ETH and releases it when proposals pass üóùÔ∏è
  • Governor: developed by Compound, it manages proposals, voting rules, and quorum üó≥Ô∏è

These smart contracts work together to define how proposals are made, approved and executed, all automatically and onchain ‚ö°

This kind of modular approach is one of Web3‚Äôs biggest strengths: shared infrastructure becomes a public good of its own, ready to be remixed, repurposed, and reimagined üí≠

slides.title: How Onchain Funding Works
slides.content:
To understand onchain funding, here‚Äôs a brief summary of how it works:

üé® Step 1: the auction contract creates a new Public Noun every 12 hours (or when the past auction is settled), and sends the ETH from each auction directly to the treasury.

üó≥Ô∏è Step 2: the governor contract manages proposals and voting made by DAO members - only when a proposal passes, meeting quorum and approval thresholds, can it be executed.

üí∞ Step 3: the treasury contract holds the funds and is only triggered by the governor contract, often with a built-in time delay.

This setup means funds move only when the community approves. No shortcuts, no central admin, no backroom decisions.

In simple terms, it‚Äôs a protocol for funding: transparent, automatic, and verifiable by anyone on the Ethereum blockchain. Check out the full contract here on Etherscan.
